man great soeuer present himselfe king tat • ered roabe couers good garment end al pōpe remain king shew himselfe much pomp great traine prince well aduised therin rather follow way ancient magnificum saith tacitus laetumque 〈◊〉 ti sociorum auxiliis ambiri ne que indigere stately bee offered great succor ally need thē able passe without german told king hee declare himselfe duke would make accord make warre king king saw farre behind thought affaiers could long prosper duke enterprise succeed swiss swiss aduertised resolution assaile prepared let know desire comand naturall himthe swiss craue peace duke bourgundy resolution defend themselues also natural vnto themthere people found neuer simple submit themselues volontarily seruitude without defēce resistance natural siciliens saith hermo crate seeke domineere ouer doe willingly submit themselues proper mā defend himselfe iniuries one would doe thucid lay al blame vpon sent deputy beseech leaue peace offer forsake alliance cōsistory dura re videbaturminusque aestimationi apostolicae dignitatis conueniens ad corum condemnatorum que nutum nullā poenitentiae significationē edentium irrogatas poenas suspendi diesque tantum octo ad eam suspensionem edici peruersa cō fusa iustitiae norma haud dubiè apparebat ex reo iudicem ex iudice reū constitui porro autē cum censurae ipsae nostrae ludibtio habitae esset magistratum que imperio interdictum nullibi obseruatū omnibus locis omnia profanata ridiculum iudicabatur id suspendi quod seruatum non esset id concecedi quod sibi peccatores ante sumpsissent et enim si censuras timebāt quaerebatur cur ea spreuissent si non timebant expediens non videbatur rem iudicio peccatorum non necessariam vel concedi vel peti excommunicated made satisfaction church made demonstration repentance held distastefull thing accused prescribe law vnto iudge iudge duty accused accused performe office iudge ridiculous thing demand suspension beene obserued grant already cessation armes make peace many treaty beene made within without italy heate armes suspension might onely losse also danger course correction broken men mind grew incorrigible obstinate yet embassadours france shew priuate consideration could haue great effect generall common good christendome peace venetian made let soueraigne power italy might ioyne together resist turke euery one binding himselfe entertaine certaine number souldiers long time thought fit vpon considerationcensures suspended truce made censure armes suspended ijs disceptandis augustijs publica charitas priuatum putauimus disscussing doubt publicke charity preuailed ouer priuate interest inclining desire french embassadours deliuered king name mediation commandement procuring peace haue relinquished owne right thought good surcease embassadours venice florence fall examination article finde pleasing vnto make new demand wil haue restored ben taken war passe ouer pope interest respect highly say plainely affaire changed estate made peace turke declared would maintain constantly fullyconditiōs peace refused demanding absolution forme church meaningpia insuper sanctaque impiè nefandissimè occisorum christianorum domini suffragià cardinalis legati detensionē ambagibus quibusdam praetereunt qui vero monumentū declinandum existiment si nostram eam infamiam putant aequo animo per deum superflui officij curam deponant nam conscientia pluris est nobis quam omniū sermo benefactis quorum testis est deus malorū calumnias veras nobis laudes adscribimus discrimen iniustae criminationis malumus subire quam tot defunctorum anima refrigerio iusto carere qui si ad seipsos eam infamiam referunt imiè que factorū delere de ciuita • e memoriā cupiunt sunt haud dubiè seipsos mortuos duri ad iterandam enim contritionem proximis que praebendum exemplum subleu andum que imprimis extinctorum anima stare ante oculos peccatum volunt durae nimirum recusationis suae culpa haec est non gaspe death ❧the history lewis eleuenth tenth booke beginning yeare 14801480 lewis beganne dye feare death come neuer fitly brings terrour amazementlife must bee considered end bee good glorious rest proportionable quomodo fabula sic vita non quandiu sed quam bene acta sit refert nil ad rem pertinet quo lo • desinas quocun que vole desine tantum bonam clausulam imponas life like vnto fable import long well acted skils thou leauest leaue thou wilt thy conclusion good sen force grew weake courage fortefied strong vpon apprehensiō would make designes vpon graue would stay vntill hee came end carriere hee desired end authority maiesty reputation begonne would know dying hold mortall hee workes west life shadow reputation respect great nooneday raigne yet find iudgement hath force vigour formerly remainder life become sowerage alwaies accompanied age come alonewhen wine life grow low become sowre antiphanes hauing brought diuers discommodities incorrigible melancholy agitation minde slow feuer paine emerauds hath prouision hath way go gather lay vp hee abandon let goage becomes couetous hath need good feares earth faile one demanded symonides sparing extremity age said rather course affaire doth turne day night although life passeth away languishing griefe yet rather endure paine desiring rather freed life painefull soeuer hath houre easethere • life languishing full paine consules duce iudices quorum vitas merita aetates familias et gesta non nouerit god forbid prince father countrey tearmed children▪ whose hand maisters must hold subscribe drawne giue office childish delight misery haue emperour knowes maintaine fame▪ commonweale feares tutor subiect stripe terror shall make consul duke iudges whose liues merites age family action hee doth know ill himselfe worse subiects mother elenor sister iohn second king arragon depriued estate regency father left peter duke coimbra caused bee poysoned alphonso tooke armes reuenge mother death peter slaine lisbone poysoned arrow would haue married alphonso ioane supposed daughter henry fourth king castille tragedy hath beene formerly plaid died sinta nine forty yeares old yeare one thousand foure hundred eighty two three fortith reigne interred royall monastery battell order preaching frier warres betwixt king castille vnfortunate voyage made france hee nothing languish saw forst passe france succor fortune affliction hee hath beene long sea stormes tempest hath neuer arriued safe port cannot say hath sayled much hath bene long tossed tempest like manner hee hath liued long cross life cannot say life hath beene long hee hath continued long waues world hee dyed griefe haue done thing world dying carryeth marke old age departeth shamefully life lewis 11 left remorse haue beene idle haue let torrent pulpit iohn ball english priest went preach seditiously field causing himselfe followed people hearing 200000 began tearmes god would haue made distinction amongst men would haue ordained difference like poyson cup gold haue often obserued eloquent discourse word scarce intellegible without discourse reason haue put people heard choler easily passion cōmunicate word passe speaks heares iealousy hee added humble prayer wrong sacred thing wisedome god hath left prince felicity estate admonition haue preuailed maiestie hath motion effect seemed contrary iustice haue made see cause time men
